user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_daemon_info:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN const union MHD_DaemonInfo *
MHD_get_daemon_info (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                     enum MHD_DaemonInfoType info_type,
                     ...)
{
  if (NULL == daemon)
    return NULL;

  mhd_assert ((0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) || \
              (NULL != daemon->worker_pool) || \
              (MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));
  mhd_assert (((0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) &&
               (NULL == daemon->worker_pool)) || \
              (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));

  switch (info_type)
  {
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_MAC_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_LISTEN_FD:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd.listen_fd = daemon->listen_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_EPOLL_FD:
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd.epoll_fd = daemon->epoll_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd;
#else  /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
    return NULL;
#endif /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_CURRENT_CONNECTIONS:
    if (! MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon))
      MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    else if (daemon->worker_pool)
    {
      unsigned int i;
      /* Collect the connection information stored in the workers. */
      daemon->connections = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < daemon->worker_pool_size; i++)
      {
        /* FIXME: next line is thread-safe only if read is atomic. */
        daemon->connections += daemon->worker_pool[i].connections;
      }
    }
#endif
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections.num_connections
      = daemon->connections;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_FLAGS:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags.flags = daemon->options;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_BIND_PORT:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port.port = daemon->port;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port;
  default:
    return NULL;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No fragments need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. The rule forbids modifying a function parameter itself (and for pointer parameters, forbids modifying the pointer value), but permits modifying the object the pointer points to. In this function: - The pointer parameter 'daemon' is never reassigned (no statements like 'daemon = ...'), so the pointer itself is not modified. - The non-pointer parameter 'info_type' is not modified. - All assignments target members of the object pointed to by 'daemon' (for example, daemon->daemon_info_dummy_... and daemon->connections). Modifying the pointed-to object's members is allowed by the rule. - The variadic arguments are not used/modified. - Returning addresses of members of *daemon does not modify any parameter. - The mhd_assert and conditional checks only read fields and do not assign to the parameters. Therefore there are no violations of Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
